title: Pla Rad Prik (Crispy Fish)
description: Whole fish deep-fried until ultra-crispy and topped with a bright, tangy-sweet-spicy Thai chili sauce. The dish balances crunchy texture with layers of garlic, lime, fish sauce and palm sugar for a vibrant finish.

ingredients.notes: about 1.5–1.8 lb (cleaned), score both sides with 3 shallow diagonal cuts
coat fish lightly for extra crisp

ingredients.display_name: neutral oil for deep frying (vegetable or peanut oil)
ingredients.notes: enough for deep frying in a wok or deep pan (approx. 900 ml)

ingredients.display_name: thai red chilies, sliced (adjust to taste)
palm sugar (or light brown sugar), grated
ingredients.notes: adjust to taste for balanced sweet-tart sauce
optional, for extra color and umami

ingredients.display_name: fried garlic or shallot crisps (optional garnish)

steps.text: Prepare the fish: rinse and pat the whole fish dry, score 3 diagonal cuts on each side, then season inside and out with salt and white pepper; let rest for 5 minutes.
Dust the fish evenly with cornstarch, shaking off excess so there is a thin, even coating over the skin and cavities.
Heat oil in a deep wok or heavy pot to 350°F (175°C) — enough oil to submerge most of the fish; use a thermometer or test with a small piece of batter to confirm steady sizzling.

Carefully lower the fish into the hot oil using long tongs or a slotted spatula; fry on the first side until crisp and golden, about 5–6 minutes, then carefully flip and fry the other side until cooked through and deeply golden, about another 5–6 minutes. Adjust heat to maintain 325–350°F.
Transfer the fried fish to a wire rack set over a sheet tray to drain and keep crisp while you make the sauce.
Make the rad prik sauce: heat a tablespoon of oil in a small skillet over medium heat, add minced garlic and sliced shallots, sauté until fragrant and just turning golden, about 1–2 minutes.

Add sliced Thai chilies and sauté briefly (30–40 seconds), then add fish sauce, palm sugar, lime juice, rice vinegar, water and optional light soy sauce; simmer gently until sugar dissolves and sauce thickens slightly, about 2–3 minutes. Taste and adjust balance of sweet, sour and salty.
Pour the hot sauce evenly over the crispy fish (or spoon it across the top), allowing some sauce to reach the scored cuts so it flavors the flesh.
Garnish with sliced scallions, cilantro leaves and fried garlic/shallot crisps if using. Serve immediately with steamed jasmine rice.
